  4802. it came earlier than expected very grateful of that.
  4803. None of my older brushes could survive my rough handling and cleaning
  4804. As I use it to smooth out the foundation the thick bristles pressed the cream deep into the pores and therefore show up unflatteringly.
  4805. The brush was in good condition upon opening, and unfortunately broke after minimal use.
  4806. I usually pat it down for more coverage .
  4807. Even cheapy brushes don't usually have loose ferrules, and considering how much this cost, it doesn't exactly fall under the cheapy category.
  4808. good brush, but unfortunately the stick part came loose and now i only use the bristle part of it.
  4809. (It's important that you know that it has only been in the past year that I've been buying more expensive make-up vs. drugstore stuff
  4810. All I used to wash it, was a little olive oil, soap and water, which works wonders on my other, cheap brushes, from target.
  4811. When I finally started to use it, however, I found that it was absorbing more of my liquid foundation than my ELF Powder brush (which I won't tolerate, seeing that right now, I'm using Make Up For Ever's HD Foundation, which is too expensive to be wasted!!)
  4812. It is a long lasting brush and you won't have to worry about having to get a new one anytime soon
  4813. I did wash it right away and it only shed a few hairs.
  4814. Anyway, I am paranoid about being out and having a stubble show through late in the day, and this brush combined with the right foundation (and stippling!) buys me a lot of time.
  4815. The one drawback is that it is very dense, and takes a long time to dry.
  4816. I don't think that can really be considered a con since ALL synthetic fiber brushes take long to dry
  4817. I had previously purchased the &#34;Sephora&#34; version of this brush, and all it did from the first day was shed...everywhere and constantly.
  4818. I have used MUG's stippling brush in the past, and to me this one is better and slightly cheaper.
  4819. Every time I use it, I always use more foundation than if I use my other brush, it also highlights my dry spots on my forehead making an uneven and spotty finish.
  4820. Lately I've been on the fence about buying super expensive foundation and instead opted for this brush after seeing it used in many makeup tutorials online in the hopes that having a 'professional' tool would help me out with what I already have.<br /><br
  4821. My combination skin is mostly in great shape, but I'v been disappointed with cakey or too watery foundations.
  4822. I was a bit disappointed about the shedding given the great reviews.
  4823. have to confess that I have a facial hair problem due to very aggravating disorder that drives me nuts.
  4824. The only thing is it is a bit hard to clean.
  4825. This brush is really hard to completely clean back to
  4826. The bristles are soft they do not loosen or break even after a long time of use.
  4827. (especially the bare minerals buki brushes which shed at an obnoxious rate).
  4828. It doesn't waste product and it doesn't shed, even straight out of the box!
  4829. I love that this buffs product into the skin and disperses any extra that you might not want left behind.
  4830. but I had no idea what I was missing until I tried my first Sigma brush.
  4831. So first time I discover this brush was watching a few tutorials on You Tube.
  4832. Price is absolutely affordable and way cheaper than what you find on ebay and by any other carries of these sigma brushes!
  4833. I am very careful with the way I wash my brushes however this particular brush did not hold up to the sigma quality.
  4834. I was not willing to pay $30 & up for a high end brush that might work, so I stuck with my fingers.
  4835. Yes I will purchase other one and highly recommend to family and friends.
  4836. , I really do, but I thought it was going to make my foundation look AMAZING, so I was a bit disappointed.
  4837. It is also incredibly soft to the touch but sturdy enough to not completely give way while you are applying foundation.
  4838. The next day after my first use, I washed the brush and there was little fallout, only about 1 or 2 bristles.
  4839. The bristle began to push down and honestly it became unusable after approximately 8 washes.
  4840. It is totally worth the $23 I spent, I can't wait to the other brushes in the line!
  4841. The brush is super soft and very thick.
  4842. The bristles are soft and dense and I haven't shed a single fiber yet
  4843. Now I think I want one that's not flat though.
  4844. Also the brush is not easy to clean, takes a long time to dry.
  4845. brush is very durable as well, I've had it a little over a year now
  4846. The bristles didnt come off at all, which is a problem ive had with other new brushes.
  4847. The brush absorbs too much foundation and little is actually left to apply on the skin.
  4848. I typically use ELF studio line brushes which are extremely affordable but also durable and useful.
  4849. It is definitely worth the money, also Sigma has way better brushes than Mac and other expensive brands for almost half the price.

  4851. Anyway, basically this product loses stars because it took forever to get here (Canada) and the brush requires A LOT of wrist action so that can lead to a lot of fatigue (and my mom won't use it for that reason) and if you are doing make up for a while, it gets to be way too much.

  43. I bought this after seeing countless YouTube beauty gurus recommend this brush over and over again. After seeing this brush recommended so many times I had pretty high expectations. People were claiming it gave you an &#34;airbrushed finish&#34; and saying it was their favorite makeup brush ever. I took a chance ordering it from amazon not knowing if I would get a fake brush or not. After reading through the Sigma website, they state which companies are certified sellers of their brushes. The company that was selling this brush through amazon was one listed on the Sigma website so I felt confident that I would get a genuine brush. Once I received it, I was shocked how soft and dense the brush was. I washed it before I used it and it did not shed any bristles. I use it almost every time I put on foundation and it is now my favorite way to apply foundation. It really does give the most coverage and while I don't know how an airbrushed finish looks, it is the best my foundation has ever looked. The only negative I can think of is that it is really hard to wash the product out of the brush because the brush is so dense. I washed it multiple times and there is still traces of foundation in the center. Overall, I would highly recommend trying this brush.
  44. This is a great brush for blending your finished look together, but I bought it for applying cream/ liquid/ mineral foundation. I will never use another brush again to apply my foundation. This is fantastic! Buffs the foundation in so easily (I use Clinique Even Better Skin foundation). Gets into the crease of my nose, under my eyes, around my hairline all with easy. This brush is perfect in my small girly hand. After two days of use, I washed it again (with Dr. Bonner's Peppermint liquid soap, a little drop in warm soapy water, just swishing brush into a cup of the soapy water, rinse the cup, add just warm water and dip the brush in and swishing until all traces of makeup was gone, then using my fingers to push off excess water and allow to air dry), absolutely no fall out, the brush was still soft and ready to use the next day. This is a two thumbs up kind of brush for me.

  173. Before getting this brush, I tried a lot of other ways to apply liquid foundation (with a traditional foundation brush, sponges, fingers, etc) but nothing worked to really blend my foundation and make it look somewhat natural. I decided to try this brush after seeing it used in a tutorial on Youtube, and I'm really glad I did. The brush is really soft and dense, and made my face look like it was airbrushed after blending my foundation. It doesn't absorb a lot of the foundation like sponges or other brushes so I don't have to keep putting more foundation on, and it really buffs the product onto my skin so it doesn't look cakey/uneven. It has even saved me time on applying my foundation, since it blends it so quickly.<br /><br />The brush is very durable as well, I've had it a little over a year now and it still looks brand new. I haven't had shedding issues with it either. It can be somewhat difficult to get completely clean using regular brush cleaner or baby shampoo, I've been using Dawn dish detergent to clean it and it works great (and quickly). I would definitely recommend this brush, as well as many of the other high quality Sigma brushes.

About 6 months into use the brush started to shed terribly and then it just got to the point that I could no longer use it. I went to sigma.com and put in a complaint. They replied quickly and said that they would contact the seller and tell them about my trouble. I got an email the next day from the amazon seller etailz and they sent me out a new brush! This new brush has been great with no shedding at all and seems better put together than the last one. I think the one I had gotten before must have been a dud.

I'm not saying that I don't like this brush, I do, but if I had to do it all over again I probably would have left it where I found it. It is definately not a \\"must have\\" by any means. If you have the extra money and are into makeup brushes then it's worth checking out. But if you are buliding your makeup brushes and makeup collection, I would reccomend checking e.l.f brushes.

I also told them that I threw the brush away and have bought a replacement. I really do not expect to hear from them.<br />I really want people to know they are a friendly, helpful company until you have problems. There are lots of brushes that are just as good and cheaper now on amazon. Amazon is a wonderful place to purchase anything because they care and are always helpful after the sale is complete and they have your money. So sad that Sigma is not like amazon.<br />Amazon you are all doing a wonderful job.<br /><br />This is an update to my review..<br />I never heard from sigma but did receive a replacement brush in the mail today.<br />I guess they took my last email seriously. I must say that I like the brushes that I have bought from them.<br />I hope others do not have a any problems with their brushes and if they do, the customer service at sigma is helpful.

  753. I hemmed and hawed over purchasing this brush because I am very skeptical about online reviews since some can be fake or exaggerated, but I finally broke down and bought it after watching a review video on YouTube. I'm so glad I did!!!<br /><br />I used to apply my foundation with my hands until I bought an E.L.F foundation brush at my local Target. It seemed fine so I was using it for a long while as I debated this brush. (It's important that you know that it has only been in the past year that I've been buying more expensive make-up vs. drugstore stuff so I could never justify spending so much for a make-up application brush.)<br /><br />This brush is truly amazing! First of all, I purchased it from Etailz, one of the Sigma approved Amazon retailers. As a Prime member, I received my brush in two days in perfect condition and I am positive it is a real Sigma product as it has all the markers other reviewers said a real brush should have. Then I used the brush and I was blown away at how flawless my foundation came out that day! The brush is super soft and dense and the product just went on perfectly. I applied like I always do: pumped some product onto the back of my hand, dipped my brush in, and started at the center of my face, working my way out and up with smooth, circular strokes. I worked it all in and was thrilled at the the end result.<br /><br />Now, I am going to say that I am a firm believer that the foundation you use makes a huge difference as well (I use YSL Touche Eclat so it's a higher-end foundation that itself goes on flawlessly) but I most definitely noticed a difference between the application with the E.L.F brush and this one - there was absolutely no comparison!<br /><br />This brush is my new go to and I would re-purchase it in a heartbeat. Just be sure to purchase either from one of the approved sellers so you know you're getting a real Sigma brush (another reviewer listed them in a previous review) or go right through Sigma. I went with Amazon b/c of the super fast, free shipping from Prime. You won't regret your purchase, I promise! :)nt with Amazon b/c of the super fast, free shipping from Prime. You won't regret your purchase, I promise! :)

  757. I'm a little late in writing this review, but better late than never. I purchased this brush in March'13. My first time using this brush, I was already really disappointed with the quality. First off the ferrule was loose. I always wash my new brushes before using them and always lay them flat to dry, so I'm pretty sure it was loose beforehand. Even cheapy brushes don't usually have loose ferrules, and considering how much this cost, it doesn't exactly fall under the cheapy category. I have to hold the ferrule with the handle when I'm using this brush so that it won't move, so you can imagine how annoying that is. Second, a few of the hairs on the brush are longer than others. Yeah, so I'm not really happy with this purchase and probably won't purchase another Sigma brush again.

AI understand that the products may cost more in the stores, but at least you get a better guarantee. Also it is $2.00 cheaper on the website, so try the Sigma website. At least on their website your purchase is guaranteed with money back if you are not satisfied with your purchase.   855. I've always been a bit wary and skeptical of face/foundation brushes, due to the fact I've had little luck with them when it comes to achieving as flawless an application as something like a dampened sponge applicator or beauty wedge. This is primarily because I suffer from severely sensitive, dry, dehydrated skin, and eczema, which is easily irritated by most all makeup brushes. Additionally, most makeup brushes, no matter how soft, tend to cause too much flaking and exfoliation on my skin, so buffing in any sort of foundation with any brush is typically out of the question. The Sigma F80, however, is phenomenal at getting you as close to an airbrushed perfect application, without any streaking, flaking, or patchiness that I've had with any other foundation brushes. Whether using liquid or mineral foundation, this brush provides the perfect finish and doesn't irritate or flake my skin. I recommend it to anyone and everyone, as the only thing better that I've found is actual airbrushing!

I also have found that I use less product with this brush, this is probably due to the fact that the brush is made with the synthetic Sigmax fibers and is extremely dense. I can't say enough about this brush it's amazing and for anyone who wears foundation I believe it's a must have. It will change your life. I tried hard to think about what are the cons of the brush and the only one I could think of is the drying time. I don't think that can really be considered a con since ALL synthetic fiber brushes take long to dry so it was expected. Let's cross our fingers and hope it's true because I swear that it will make us gern-o-phobes excited to see our brushes will be drying a lot faster.<br /><br />Overall Recommendation: Buy this Brush!!!aster. I also had to start using a different makeup because I was using Clinique acne solutions which has salicitic acid, and you can't use that when pregnant. So after trying a few I finally tried MAC studio fix which works great and I needed something with full coverage...so back to the brush, when I use a sponge with this foundation it looks ok, but when I use the Sigma brush with my foundation I get a fuller coverage and the finish is so nice! It looks smooth and more professional. I also use it to put a little concealer on after when I have a particular break out. I just make sure to wash the brush every week or two to keep it nice and clean and in good condition. I am rambling because I really love this brush.
  876. I have to report the brush I received from NG Inc through Amazon as fake. The brush they sent was made in China. I have emailed Sigma to verify their brushes are indeed made in the US. I thought NG Inc stood for NutraGroup Inc, an approved Amazon Sigma reseller, but apparently it does not.<br /><br />I knew immediately the brush was not authentic when feeling the denseness of the bristles...nothing like the F82 I ordered directly from Sigma. The bristles are of low quality, with shiney, plasticky black strands. My F82 has browner, and much softer bristles...more like fine animal hair.<br /><br />If I hear from Sigma that their brushes are made in China, and NG is an authorized reseller, I'll edit this post. As of now, I'm returning the brush. The quality is not what my expectations are.<br /><br />Careful who you order from.

I use it with liquid foundation and it buffs on the skin with almost an airbrush finish. I start out by putting the foundation on the brush then patting it on the areas that need more coverage then I begin buffing all over my face. When I am done buffing I will go back over any areas that need a little extra attention. I have been using this brush for awhile and have not had any of the brush hairs fall out. That is a pet peeve of mine to be applying foundation and have little brush hairs attached to my face. It is a little pricey but well worth it for the affect you get with your makeup application.

  946. I was really excited to try this brush considering all the great reviews. When I got it in the mail, I found it to be packaged very nicely, the bristles of the brush protected well. Before I used it I made sure to wash the brush and when I did so, some minor shedding occurred. The minor shedding continued when I actually used the brush for the first time. I was a bit disappointed about the shedding given the great reviews. I also found that buffing the liquid foundation on my face was not so effortless. I don't know if it's my technique, the foundation I'm using, or just my brush, but I found that buffing the foundation required a bit of force. Other than those two things, I found the brush to be incredibly soft and dense. Once I finish buffing the foundation, the coverage is very even and smooth. To ensure that my brush dries faster, after I wash it I usually spread out the bristles a little and let it air dry. Doing that, my brush dries in about 3 hours. This is my first flat top kabuki brush, so I don't have any other similar brush to compare it to. Overall, it's a good quality brush that should last a while if you take care of it.

The handle of the brush is very sturdy and because its thick, you get great control during use. Sigma claims this is a dense brush and let me tell you, they are not kidding! This is the densest brush I have ever used! Its perfect for applying and blending my liquid foundation! I was impressed with the first application and I wanted to review it right away, but I knew my review would not be credible without having used it and washed it at least once first. The next day after my first use, I washed the brush and there was little fallout, only about 1 or 2 bristles. Also, the color of my foundation came off easily and the brush looked white on the tips again. Then I set it out to dry. This is where I kind of had a problem. The brushed didn't fluff up after drying, but I noticed the outer bristles were kind of way and they poked my hand when I touched it to see of it was dry. When I used it for the second time, my foundation still applied nicely with the brush, but the outer bristles did poke me. I'm not sure if I got a defective brush or something, but when I use it, I try to use the side without the wavy bristles. This is a little annoying. Overall, I am satisfied and I would recommend this to a friend.

I find myself using this brush with a matte powder to set my foundation by sort of pressing and dabbing it where I have my foundation on. Then I'll go over that and buff out the excess. (this technique is also great for oily skin!)<br /><br />Also, I had some speculation that this seller might be sending out fake brushes. I'm not familiar with Sigma's line (as this is my first one) but a lot of people have complained about getting fake brushes from eBay and Amazon retailers. (Some have said that the brushes have fallen apart, the bristles are less dense and/or are longer than the \\"real\\" brushes, and that the Sigma signature on the handle is different) If you want this brush, I would suggest you get it from the Sigma site and pay the few extra dollars. I've heard that it comes with a free gift too, so that's a plus! I kind of regret not purchasing it from the Sigma site .. but oh well! What can you do?<br /><br />**** UPDATE ****<br /><br />It is now December 5, 2013, so I've had this brush for little over a year. I've washed it regularly throughout the year without any problems, except for the last time. The glue that held the bristles together broke down, causing it to shed until it came off completely. I've heard that this brush has lasted people for years and years, but that wasn't the case for me! It completely fell apart and I had to throw it out. It was really disappointing because I've probably had my ELF brushes longer than this one and I have yet to have a problem with shedding.

With my others Sigmas I have never had a problem with the hairs falling out. Also I can definitely smell paint on the brush, the Sigma logo is painted on and the whole brush reeks of paint.   1221. I have long been on the quest for the perfect liquid foundation brush.<br /><br />To provide a little bit of my foundation brush history:<br />I went through a phase where I religiously used the MAC 190, but I always felt it left my face streaky. Not to mention the 190 application can be a bit arduous and meticulous. Eventually, I tried the stippling craze, and I attempted to use the MAC 187, but the fibers just weren't dense enough. It's great for light application of powders, but for any sort of MATTE look, the 187 is not a good choice. Next, I found surprising success with the ELF studio powder brush, which, for three dollars was impressive. But, the ELF brush shed like crazy (handfuls of taklon fibers fell out-- it was gross).<br /><br />BUT FINALLY, I found my holy grail, liquid foundation brush in the Sigma F80 flat top kabuki. It is everything i ever wanted in a foundation brush -- good quality (not flimsy or loose handle like the ELF powder brush), it has dense synthetic fibers, and most importantly, it applies all of my liquid foundations like a dream (MAC studiofix, Revlon Colorstay-- you name it). I am a fan of a matte, full coverage finish, which is why the F80 really appealed to me.<br /><br />I use this brush by stippling the foundation (as you would a MAC 187) all over my face, and then swirling and buffing it in. The dense fibers never leave a streaky finish. 100% recommended. I am eager to try the other sigma kabukis now!

  1339. This brush feels incredibly soft on the skin, blends foundation beautifully, and does a good job getting around tough places (e.g., the nose). I have used it mainly with Lancome Teint Idole foundation and the Tarte Amazonian Clay foundation. Here are my thoughts compared to a few other brushes in my collection:<br /><br />Real Techniques Buffing Brush: The Sigma F80 is better for foundation. I do like the buffing brush with BB creams, but if I want to wear a foundation that is tougher to blend, the F80 is superior. I have fewer streaking issues with the F80 and I feel that I get a fuller coverage.<br /><br />Tarte Foundation Brush: This brush leaves a beautiful finish for the Tarte Amazonian Clay Foundation BUT it is not great for getting into crevices and smaller spaces. The F80 is a lot better. It blends flawlessly all over the face.<br /><br />Real Techniques Expert Face Brush: This brush is good for BB creams and tinted moisturizers but it is really prone to streaking. The F80 is definitely worth the extra cash compared to the Real Techniques brush for tougher to blend foundations like Estee Lauder Double Wear or Tarte Amazonian Clay.<br /><br />This brush is fairly easy to wash, though the Tarte Amazonian Clay is a bear to clean if I don't wash it right away (an issue with that foundation for ALL brushes).

It applies the powder foundation very evenly and I've found that I can quickly build coverage in spots that need a little extra foundation.<br /><br />Cleaning the brush has been very easy, just a little liquid soap and water to rinse out any built up product. I have very fair skin and it was always such a challenge to blend at the chin & neck area.<br /><br />I thought it was all about the foundation. And while that is true to some degree, you don't have to spend $40+ on high end foundation. Using Revlon PhotoReady liquid foundation along with this brush DID THE TRICK! I couldn't believe the results I got. This brush is in one word AMAZING. Very soft, but also dense and firm which is what you need. It stands up to even the most rigid stippling techniques. So incredibly well made, this brush has almost no shedding and is so easy to care for.<br /><br />To those of you looking to get the finish you see in the media? Buy this brush. It is worth every cent. In my case, one full pump of foundation mixed with a small amount of Smashbox's green foundation primer, along with this brush and I finally got the airbrushed finish I was in search for.<br /><br />And no, I don't work for any company that makes any of the products I mentioned.   1443. This brush works great for giving you a fabulous airbush finish no matter what foundation you use. The only qualm I have is that you have to keep it absolutley clean for it to work it's best, if it's not clean it makes me break out and the foundation looks cakey. I wash mine with a mixture of olive oil and dish soap about once a week. It takes 24 hours to fully dry, and I make sure to stand it up ON IT'S BRISTLES to dry to make sure no water gets down into the glue of the brush. I would say it is worth the money, just make sure you are really taking the time to blend your foundation with the brush to get the best airbrush effect, and take extra time blending when the brush isn't the cleanest ;)

It really does look more silky, well blended - no streaking. I couldn't believe the difference! Even my friends noticed!

  1556. This is the best brush for liquid foundation I've used. It packs on coverage. In order to achieve the fullest coverage stipple on the foundation. Make sure you press it into the skin well for best results. For a lighter coverage, use a buffing motion. I have washed this brush several times with no shedding and the ferrule has not came loose. The bristles feel soft on my face and are densely packed. It takes a little product a long way, preventing cakey-ness. It's a high quality product at a good price considering it will last forever instead of having to repurchase $10 brushes that do have the job. If you're looking for lighter coverage, I would recommend a stippling brush, or something with less dense bristles. For me, I prefer to get the most coverage out of foundations without cakey-ness. This brush delivers that. I look forward to using this brush everyday.
